item description: Multiply two polynomial expressions.
Domain: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
Standard Description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under
certain operations.

item description: Evaluate a quadratic function for different input values.
Standard Description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context. For example, given a function representing a car loan, determine the balance of the loan at different points in time.

item description: Use an inscribed right triangle to determine the circumference of a circle.
Standard Description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.

item description: Identify transformations that would produce a congruent figure.
Standard Description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

item description: Solve for one variable in a system of linear equations algebraically.
Standard Description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.

item description: Factor a trinomial expression.
Standard Description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see (x + 2)2 – 9 as a difference of squares that can be factored as ((x + 2) + 3)((x + 2 ) – 3).

item description: Graph the solution set of a linear inequality in two variables.
Standard Description:
Graph the solutions of a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the
case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set of a system of linear inequalities in two variables
as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

item description: Identify an equation of a line perpendicular to a given line.
Standard Description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

item description: Evaluate expressions involving radicals and rational exponents.
Standard Description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

item description: Compare measures of center and spread of two data sets.
Standard Description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

item description: Find the midpoint of a line segment graphed on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

item description: Calculate conditional probabilities of real-world events from a description.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B’s outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

item description: Find the solutions of a quadratic equation in one variable.
Standard Description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

item description: Interpret data in a data display and compare the measures of center of the data sets.
Standard Description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

item description: Estimate the solution of a real-world problem using units.
Standard Description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

item description: Use similarity criteria to identify and name similar triangles.
Standard Description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the Angle-Angle (AA) criterion for two triangles to be similar.

item description: Factor a quadratic trinomial expression.
Standard Description:
Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions. For example, the expression 1.15t
can be rewritten as (1.151/12) 12t ≈ 1.01212t to reveal the approximateequivalent monthly interest rate if the annual rate is 15%.

item description: Graph a figure on a coordinate plane after a dilation.
Standard Description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

item description: Consider and complete statements about operations with rational and irrational numbers.
Standard Description:
Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number
and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an
irrational number is irrational.

item description: Determine the solution set of a linear inequality in one variable.
Standard Description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

item description: Use a trigonometric ratio to determine a missing side length in a right triangle.
Standard Description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

item description: Calculate the volume of a right square pyramid.
Standard Description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

item description: Complete a two-way table that represents a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

item description: Identify a graph that does not represent a functional relationship.
Standard Description: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output (range) of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

item description: Graph a figure on a coordinate plane after a reflection.
Standard Description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

item description: Calculate the perimeter of a parallelogram shown on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles (e.g., using the distance formula).

item description: Calculate the volume of a sphere.
Standard Description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

item description: Compare the properties of linear functions represented in different ways.
Standard Description:
Translate among different representations of functions (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables,
or by verbal descriptions). Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way. 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for Mathematics 113
For example, given a graph of one quadratic function and an algebraic expression for another, say
which has the larger maximum.

item description: Interpret part of an expression that represents a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity. For example, interpret P(1 + r)t as the product of P and a factor not depending on P.

item description: Describe transformations that create congruent and non-congruent images and determine the coordinates of the vertices of transformed figures.
Standard Description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

item description: Justify each step in the solution of a linear equation.
Standard Description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify or refute a solution method.

item description: Determine the number of sides of a regular polygon based on the measures of its exterior angles.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about parallelograms. Theorems include: opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely, rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals.

item description: Use dimensional analysis to equate actual distances and those on a map.
Standard Description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

item description: Use similar triangles to determine a missing side length.
Standard Description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

item description: Create exponential equations from a formula and use them to solve real-world problems.
Standard Description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. (Include equations arising from linear, quadratic, and exponential functions with integer exponents.)

item description: Use the Pythagorean theorem to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

item description: Identify the features of a linear function from values in a table and write an equation for another linear function shown on a graph.
Standard Description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (including reading these from a table).

item description: Determine a system of two-variable equations based on a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

item description: Identify a transformation that would carry a figure onto itself.
Standard Description: . Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself

item description: Interpret parameters of linear functions based on a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function (of the form f(x) = bx + k) in terms of a context.

item description: Determine the area of a sector of a circle.
Standard Description: Derive, using similarity, the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

item description: Identify the method for drawing the line of best fit for data displayed in a scatter plot.
Standard Description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.

item description: Determine which graph shows a triangle and its image after a dilation.
Standard Description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

item description: Use modeling and estimation techniques to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

item description: Select the values that make a given quadratic equation true.
Standard Description: Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for Mathematics 112 technology to graph the functions and make tables of values. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear and exponential functions.

item description: Complete a histogram using a given set of data.
Standard Description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).

item description: Solve a system consisting of the equations of a line and a circle.
Standard Description: Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically. For example, find the points of intersection between the line y = –3x and the circle x2 + y2 = 3.

item description: Write equations of lines that are parallel and perpendicular to given lines passing through given points.
Standard Description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

item description: Determine whether various transformations performed on a triangle will result in a congruent image.
Standard Description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

item description: Choose a system of equations that has the same solution as a given system of linear equations.
Standard Description: Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.

item description: Determine the effect on the mean if an outlier is removed from a set of data.
Standard Description: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).

item description: Find a specified term in an arithmetic sequence that is represented by a given function.
Standard Description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context. For example, given a function representing a car loan, determine the balance of the loan at different points in time.

item description: Solve equations that contain rational and irrational numbers.
Standard Description:
Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number
and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an
irrational number is irrational.

item description: Multiply a monomial and a binomial to identify an equivalent expression.
Domain: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
Standard Description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under
certain operations.

item description: Translate between radical and exponential representations of different expressions and create a radical expression based on stated parameters.
Standard Description: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents. For example, we define 51/3 to be the cube root of 5 because we want (51/3) 3 = 5(1/3) 3 to hold, so (51/3) 3 must equal 5.

item description: Use the values of a function in a table to describe an exponential function and determine which equation models the function.
Standard Description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (including reading these from a table).

item description: Find the solutions of a quadratic equation.
Standard Description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

item description: Find a specified term in a geometric sequence, given the value of two other terms in the sequence.
Standard Description: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers. For example, the Fibonacci sequence is defined recursively by f(0) = f(1) = 1, f(n + 1) = f(n) + f(n + 1) for n ≥ 1.

item description: Use a mathematical model to estimate a quantity in a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

item description: Solve and graph a system of linear equations.
Standard Description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.

item description: Use the line of best fit for data in a scatter plot to predict a value in a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.

item description: Determine which equation describes the relationship between two variables in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

item description: Use the graphs of three different functions to compare how they increase as the independent variable increases.
Standard Description: Observe, using graphs and tables, that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

item description: Use the Pythagorean Theorem to determine the missing side length of a triangle in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

item description: Analyze an algebraic sequence that represents a real-world situation.
Standard Description:
Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula them to model
situations, and translate between the two forms.

item description: Use proportions to find a missing side length in a diagram displaying similar triangles.
Standard Description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

item description: Use the volume formula for a cone to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

item description: Locate a point on a line segment, graphed on a coordinate plane, that divides the segment in a specified ratio.
Standard Description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

item description: Calculate relative frequencies based on data displayed in a two-way table.
Standard Description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

item description: Determine the effects of rounding on measurements in a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.

item description: Use trigonometric ratios to determine a missing side length in a right triangle.
Standard Description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

item description: Match geometric terms with their definitions.
Standard Description: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.

item description: Determine the coordinates of a vertex of a triangle, graphed on a coordinate plane, after a sequence of transformations.
Standard Description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

item description: Determine the volume of a cylinder, and compare the volumes of other cylinders that have similar dimensions.
Standard Description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone. Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri’s principle, and informal limit arguments.

item description: Solve a compound linear inequality that represents a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

item description: Write and solve a linear equation and linear inequalities based on a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. (Include equations arising from linear, quadratic, and exponential functions with integer exponents.)

item description: Determine the coordinates of a vertex of a parallelogram after a reflection and the sequence of transformations that would map the parallelogram onto itself.
Standard Description: . Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself

item description: Graph the image of a point on a coordinate plane after a reflection over a given line.
Standard Description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

item description: Identify the theorem about parallel lines and transversals that proves two pairs of angles in a diagram are congruent.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about lines and angles. Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent, and conversely prove lines are parallel; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment’s endpoints.

item description: Identify the domain of a function based on a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes. For example, if the function h(n) gives the number of person-hours it takes to assemble n engines in a factory, then the positive integers would be an appropriate domain for the function

item description: Complete a two-way frequency table and use the table to calculate a conditional probability.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities. For example, collect data from a random sample of students in your school on their favorite subject among math, science, and English. Estimate the probability that a randomly selected student from your school will favor science given that the student is in tenth grade. Do the same for other subjects and compare the results.

item description: Determine the measure of an angle in a triangle inscribed in a circle.
Standard Description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.

item description: Calculate the average rate of change of an exponential function over a given interval.
Standard Description: Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.

item description: Calculate the perimeter of a trapezoid graphed on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles (e.g., using the distance formula).

item description: Determine the solution of a linear equation in one variable.
Standard Description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

item description: Create two linear equations in two variables based on a description of a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

item description: Given two similar triangles, use a proportional relationship to determine an unknown side length.
Standard Description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

item description: Factor a trinomial expression to identify an equivalent expression.
Standard Description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see (x + 2)2 – 9 as a difference of squares that can be factored as ((x + 2) + 3)((x + 2 ) – 3).

item description: Determine an expression that represents an arithmetic sequence, given its first five terms.
Standard Description:
Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula them to model
situations, and translate between the two forms.

item description: Interpret the units in a graph that represents a real-world situation and estimate solutions of associated problems.
Standard Description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

item description: Identify the triangle theorem that is illustrated by a folded paper demonstration.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include: measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°; base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent, and conversely prove a triangle is isosceles; the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the medians of a triangle meet at a point.

item description: Identify the graph of the solution set of a system of linear inequalities in two variables.
Standard Description:
Graph the solutions of a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the
case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set of a system of linear inequalities in two variables
as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

item description: Identify an equation that may not be true based on a diagram featuring parallel lines and a transversal.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about lines and angles. Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent, and conversely prove lines are parallel; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment’s endpoints.

item description: Expand a polynomial expression to create an equivalent expression.
Domain: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
Standard Description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under
certain operations.

item description: Rearrange an equation to solve for different aspects of the formula it represents.
Standard Description: Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest using the same reasoning as in solving equations (Properties of equality). For example, rearrange Ohm’s law to solve for voltage, V. Manipulate variables in formulas used in financial contexts such as for simple interest, I=Prt .

item description: Given an exponential expression, use properties of exponents to create an equivalent expression.
Standard Description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

item description: Evaluate a linear function over specific values of its domain and interpret given values of the function in terms of a real-world context.
Standard Description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context. For example, given a function representing a car loan, determine the balance of the loan at different points in time.

item description: Interpret the slope and the y-intercept of a linear model based on real-world data.
Standard Description: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.

item description: Describe a transformation of a line segment that will result in a parallel image.
Standard Description: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.

item description: Create an equation that represents the graph of a function after it has been translated.
Standard Description: Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, kf(x), f(kx), and f (x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Include linear, quadratic, exponential, and absolute value functions. Utilize technology to experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph.

item description: Factor a quadratic expression to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description:
Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions. For example, the expression 1.15t
can be rewritten as (1.151/12) 12t ≈ 1.01212t to reveal the approximateequivalent monthly interest rate if the annual rate is 15%.

item description: Rewrite different radical expressions using rational exponents.
Standard Description: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents. For example, we define 51/3 to be the cube root of 5 because we want (51/3) 3 = 5(1/3) 3 to hold, so (51/3) 3 must equal 5.

item description: Determine the coordinates of an end point of a line segment, graphed on a coordinate plane, after a rotation.
Standard Description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

item description: Determine the y-value of the solution of a system of linear equations.
Standard Description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.

item description: Determine an angle measure in a right triangle based on the relationship of two of the triangle's side lengths.
Standard Description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

item description: Determine an unknown angle measure based on a diagram of two similar triangles.
Standard Description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

item description: Compare rates that relate distance and time, given in different units.
Standard Description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

item description: Compute a conditional probability based on dependent events in a real-world situation.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B) ∕P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.

item description: Interpret the parameters of an exponential function based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function (of the form f(x) = bx + k) in terms of a context.

item description: Use dissections to find the partial circumference of a circle.
Standard Description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone. Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri’s principle, and informal limit arguments.

item description: Calculate compound and conditional probabilities from data displayed in a graph and interpret the graph in terms of the probabilities.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B’s outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

item description: Graph a triangle on a coordinate plane after a dilation.
Standard Description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

item description: Create two-variable linear equations and use them to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

item description: Determine the measure of an angle of a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.
Standard Description: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral and other polygons inscribed in a circle.

item description: Use estimation and rounding strategies to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.

item description: Calculate the perimeter and the area of a pentagon graphed on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles (e.g., using the distance formula).

item description: Interpret a histogram based on a set of real-world data.
Standard Description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).

item description: Use volume formulas for cylinders and spheres to solve real-world problems.
Standard Description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

item description: Determine the domain and range of a linear function based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes. For example, if the function h(n) gives the number of person-hours it takes to assemble n engines in a factory, then the positive integers would be an appropriate domain for the function

item description: Determine the measure of an angle in one of a pair of similar triangles.
Standard Description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the Angle-Angle (AA) criterion for two triangles to be similar.

item description: Calculate a marginal relative frequency from data in a two-way table.
Standard Description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

item description: Interpret the results of the construction of an angle bisector.
Standard Description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Constructions include: copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.

item description: Determine the area of a sector of a circle and its arc length given the radius of the circle and a central angle measure.
Standard Description: Derive, using similarity, the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

item description: Determine whether given situations can be modeled by a linear function or by an exponential function.
Standard Description: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.

item description: Determine the nature of a quadrilateral given its coordinates represented by expressions.
Standard Description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically, including the distance formula and its relationship to the Pythagorean Theorem. For example, prove or disprove that a figure defined by four given points in the coordinate plane is a rectangle; prove or disprove that the point (1, ) lies on the circle centered at the origin and containing the point (0, 2).

item description: Create a one-variable equation, based on a real-world context, and use the equation to solve a problem.
Standard Description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. (Include equations arising from linear, quadratic, and exponential functions with integer exponents.)

item description: Factor a quadratic expression to solve a problem in a real-world context.
Standard Description:
Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions. For example, the expression 1.15t
can be rewritten as (1.151/12) 12t ≈ 1.01212t to reveal the approximateequivalent monthly interest rate if the annual rate is 15%.

item description: Create the equation of a circle given its center and radius.
Standard Description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.

item description: Evaluate a radical expression that has an exponent using laws of exponents.
Standard Description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

item description: Determine the median value of real-world data displayed in a line plot.
Standard Description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).

item description: Given a polynomial expression, identify an equivalent expression.
Domain: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
Standard Description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under
certain operations.

item description: Given a line graphed on a coordinate plane, determine its slope, create an equation of a parallel line, determine whether another line is parallel, and create an equation of a perpendicular line passing through a given point.
Standard Description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

item description: Solve a linear inequality based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

item description: Identify the point on a line segment that partitions the segment into a given ratio.
Standard Description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

item description: Identify the solutions of a quadratic equation in factored form.
Standard Description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

item description: Determine the length of a leg of a right triangle based on angle measures.
Standard Description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

item description: Identify a statement about rational and irrational numbers that is not true and determine whether a given expression is rational.
Standard Description:
Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number
and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an
irrational number is irrational.

item description: Identify the equation of a line graphed on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

item description: Given a quadratic function that represents a context, evaluate the function for a specific input value, analyze how the function changes over different input values, and determine the maximum value of the function.
Standard Description: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship. Key features include: intercepts; intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums and minimums; symmetries; and end behavior.

item description: Compare properties of a quadratic function shown on a graph and another represented by values in a table.
Standard Description:
Translate among different representations of functions (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables,
or by verbal descriptions). Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way. 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for Mathematics 113
For example, given a graph of one quadratic function and an algebraic expression for another, say
which has the larger maximum.

item description: Construct an exponential function based on information in a table.
Standard Description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (including reading these from a table).

item description: Use estimation skills to approximate the solution of a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

item description: Identify the coordinates of points that lie on the graph of a linear equation.
Standard Description:
Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the
coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line). Show that any point on the graph of an
equation in two variables is a solution to the equation.

item description: Use trigonometric ratios to determine side lengths in different right triangles based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

item description: Justify each step in the solution of a linear equation.
Standard Description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify or refute a solution method.

item description: Use the Triangle Sum Theorem to determine an angle measure.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include: measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°; base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent, and conversely prove a triangle is isosceles; the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the medians of a triangle meet at a point.

item description: Identify the solution of a system of a linear equation and a quadratic equation.
Standard Description: Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically. For example, find the points of intersection between the line y = –3x and the circle x2 + y2 = 3.

item description: Calculate the area of a trapezoid graphed on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles (e.g., using the distance formula).

item description: Identify a function that represents a geometric sequence partially displayed in a table.
Standard Description:
Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula them to model
situations, and translate between the two forms.

item description: Create two one-variable equations and use them to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. (Include equations arising from linear, quadratic, and exponential functions with integer exponents.)

item description: Identify the domain and range of a linear function from its graph.
Standard Description: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output (range) of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

item description: Identify a proportion that can be used to find an unknown side length in a pair of similar triangles.
Standard Description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

item description: Complete a two-way frequency table of data, use the data in the table to compute conditional probabilities, and determine whether the variables of interest are independent.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities. For example, collect data from a random sample of students in your school on their favorite subject among math, science, and English. Estimate the probability that a randomly selected student from your school will favor science given that the student is in tenth grade. Do the same for other subjects and compare the results.

item description: Identify the graph of a triangle on a coordinate plane after a transformation.
Standard Description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

item description: Compare the parameters of three linear functions that represent a real-world context.
Standard Description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function (of the form f(x) = bx + k) in terms of a context.

item description: Analyze the construction of a square inscribed in a circle.
Standard Description: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.

item description: Compare the values of a linear function and an exponential function, graphed on a coordinate plane, as the value of the independent variable increases.
Standard Description: Observe, using graphs and tables, that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

item description: Calculate relative frequencies from a two-way table based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

item description: Determine an unknown arc measure in a diagram of a triangle inscribed in a circle.
Standard Description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.

item description: Use dimensional analysis and translate between units to solve real-world problems, and then apply the solutions to a related problem.
Standard Description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

item description: Relate the side lengths and angle measures in pairs of congruent triangles.
Standard Description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

item description: Use estimation and dimensional analysis to solve a real-world problem involving mass and money.
Standard Description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.

item description: Compare measures of center and spreads of two real-world data sets displayed in line plots.
Standard Description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

item description: Determine the coordinates of a vertex of a pentagon, graphed on a coordinate plane, after a sequence of transformations.
Standard Description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

item description: Calculate the area of a sector of a circle and the length of an arc on the circle.
Standard Description: Derive, using similarity, the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

item description: Interpret the parts of an exponential expression based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity. For example, interpret P(1 + r)t as the product of P and a factor not depending on P.

item description: Calculate the radius of a cone given its height and its volume.
Standard Description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

item description: Identify the correlation coefficient that best represents a description of the results of a survey.
Standard Description: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.

item description: Given a function that represents an arithmetic sequence, identify the first four numbers in the sequence.
Standard Description: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers. For example, the Fibonacci sequence is defined recursively by f(0) = f(1) = 1, f(n + 1) = f(n) + f(n + 1) for n ≥ 1.

item description: Given variables that represent a rational and an irrational number, identify variable expressions as rational or irrational.
Standard Description:
Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number
and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an
irrational number is irrational.

item description: Identify the equation of a line that meets given slope and intercept criteria.
Standard Description:
Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions. For example, the expression 1.15t
can be rewritten as (1.151/12) 12t ≈ 1.01212t to reveal the approximateequivalent monthly interest rate if the annual rate is 15%.

item description: Determine an unknown angle measure in a diagram with parallel lines crossed by a transversal.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about lines and angles. Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent, and conversely prove lines are parallel; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment’s endpoints.

item description: Identify a system of linear equations that has the same solution as a given system of linear equations.
Standard Description: Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.

item description: Calculate the range and the median of a set of real-world data and determine the values of additional data based on changes in measures of center.
Standard Description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

item description: Compare properties of two linear functions, one represented by an equation and the other represented by a graph.
Standard Description:
Translate among different representations of functions (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables,
or by verbal descriptions). Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way. 
Massachusetts Curriculum Framework for Mathematics 113
For example, given a graph of one quadratic function and an algebraic expression for another, say
which has the larger maximum.

item description: Determine the coordinates of the center of a circle given its equation.
Standard Description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.

item description: Identify the equation of a linear function based on values in a table.
Standard Description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (including reading these from a table).

item description: Identify an equivalent expression by finding the difference of two trinomials.
Domain: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions
Standard Description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under
certain operations.

item description: Identify a transformation rule used to map one triangle onto another, and graph the triangle over a rotation.
Standard Description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

item description: Identify the solutions of a factored quadratic equation in one variable.
Standard Description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

item description: Equate various radical expressions to exponential expressions and evaluate a claim based on the properties of exponents.
Standard Description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

item description: Calculate a marginal probability and a conditional probability based on survey data displayed in a table.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities. For example, collect data from a random sample of students in your school on their favorite subject among math, science, and English. Estimate the probability that a randomly selected student from your school will favor science given that the student is in tenth grade. Do the same for other subjects and compare the results.

item description: Identify a transformation which, if performed on a triangle, would not produce a congruent image.
Standard Description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

item description: Analyze a quadratic function that models a relationship based on a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context. For example, given a function representing a car loan, determine the balance of the loan at different points in time.

item description: Use estimation to determine a unit rate in a real-world situation involving quantities with different units.
Standard Description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

item description: Identify the graph of the solution set of a linear inequality, and identify a different inequality based on the graph of its solution set.
Standard Description:
Graph the solutions of a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the
case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set of a system of linear inequalities in two variables
as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

item description: Relate the products of binomials to their expanded forms.
Standard Description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it. For example, see (x + 2)2 – 9 as a difference of squares that can be factored as ((x + 2) + 3)((x + 2 ) – 3).

item description: Identify an equation of a line parallel to a line graphed on a coordinate plane, which passes through a given point.
Standard Description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

item description: Identify which step in the solution of an equation contains an error.
Standard Description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify or refute a solution method.

item description: Identify a transformation rule that represents the translation of a polygon on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

item description: Determine the area of a semicircle given the length of its diameter.
Standard Description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone. Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri’s principle, and informal limit arguments.

item description: Create an exponential function that models a relationship based on a real-world situation.
Standard Description:
Write linear, quadratic, and exponential functions that describe a relationship between
two quantities.

item description: Identify an exponential expression equivalent to a given radical expression.
Standard Description: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents. For example, we define 51/3 to be the cube root of 5 because we want (51/3) 3 = 5(1/3) 3 to hold, so (51/3) 3 must equal 5.

item description: Graph the image of a quadrilateral, over a dilation, on a coordinate plane.
Standard Description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

item description: Determine minor arc measures, a major arc measure, and an angle measure given a figure inscribed in a circle.
Standard Description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords. Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.

item description: Create and solve a one-variable exponential equation based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. (Include equations arising from linear, quadratic, and exponential functions with integer exponents.)

item description: Calculate the volume of a right circular cylinder given its dimensions.
Standard Description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.

item description: Use a trigonometric relationship to calculate an unknown measurement in a trapezoid.
Standard Description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.

item description: Interpret an exponential function based on the context it represents.
Standard Description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function (of the form f(x) = bx + k) in terms of a context.

item description: Relate the side lengths and angle measures in pairs of congruent triangles.
Standard Description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

item description: Analyze the construction of an angle bisector.
Standard Description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Constructions include: copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.

item description: Create and solve a system of linear equations in two variables using given constraints, and create and analyze a related inequality.
Standard Description: Represent constraints by linear equations or inequalities, and by systems of linear equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or non-viable options in a modeling context. For example, represent inequalities describing nutritional and cost constraints on combinations of different foods.

item description: Use dimensional analysis to solve real-world problems involving distance and time.
Standard Description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

item description: Calculate a relative frequency based on real-world data displayed in a two-way table.
Standard Description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

item description: Identify a sequence of transformations that can be used to prove two circles are similar.
Standard Description: Prove that all circles are similar.

item description: Identify an expression that can be used to calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring.
Domain: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability
Standard Description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B’s outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

item description: Given the graph of a quadratic function, interpret the value of the vertex and analyze other aspects of the function, based on the context it represents.
Standard Description: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship. Key features include: intercepts; intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums and minimums; symmetries; and end behavior.

item description: Use a proportion to calculate an unknown length in a diagram of a triangle and a line parallel to one of its sides.
Standard Description: Prove theorems about triangles. Theorems include: a line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two proportionally, and conversely; the Pythagorean Theorem proved using triangle similarity.

item description: Interpret the rate of change in a linear equation that models data in a real-world situation.
Standard Description: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.

item description: Calculate the measure of the central angle of a circle given the radius of the circle and the length of the arc intercepted by the angle.
Standard Description: Derive, using similarity, the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.
